text.Prompt:
Google will now scan your emails for information relevant to advertising just a bit slower thanks to a settlement of a case pending in a Northern California district court. The system will now scan those emails after they're available in the recipient's Gmail mailbox, in contrast to Google's prior practice, where the email was scanned during the delivery process.

Since each email message is scanned to deliver more relevant ads, the process meant that non-Gmail accounts were indirectly being cataloged as well. The plaintiffs in the case, which was styled Matera vs. Google, argued that this was a violation of both the Electronic Communications Privacy Act and the California Information Privacy Act, calling the strategy "the twenty-first-century equivalent of AT&T eavesdropping on each of its customers' phone conversations, or of the postal service taking information from private correspondence."

Instead of fight the case, Google agreed to change how it scans these emails — although scans for spam and malware would still occur during the delivery process as occurred before. The change will be seamless to customers, as it literally is a matter of milliseconds in processing time.

It's not clear whether Google was receiving any material benefit from the strategy — i.e. data from those non-Gmail users being used to serve more relevant ads across Google's widespread ad network. It also agreed to pay any legal costs related to the case and make a one-time payment of $2,000 to each of the class representatives.

Other ad providers have not been so lucky. Yahoo was forced to settle over similar issues with its email-related ad-targeting practices, but ended up paying close to twice what Google had to in legal costs (about $4 million).

Google declined to comment on the settlement, but offered that its efforts would result in concrete technical changes. Lawyers for the plaintiffs did not respond to a request for comment as of press time.

Editors' Recommendations

Generate a summary:
text.Response A: Google has announced that it will slow down its email scanning in order to settle a legal case pending in a Northern California district court. The system will now scan emails after they are available in the recipient's Gmail mailbox. Since each email message is scanned to deliver more relevant ads, the process meant that non-Gmail accounts were indirectly being cataloged as well. The Matera v. Google case, styled after the Electronic Communications Privacy Act and the California Information Privacy Act, called the strategy "the twenty-first-century equivalent of AT&T eavesdropping on each of its customers' phone conversations, or of the postal service taking information from private correspondence." Google declined to comment on the settlement, but offered that its efforts would result in concrete technical changes.
text.Response B: Adele's romance with grime star Skepta is said to be getting serious with rumours that she's now introduced him to her friends. Last month it was reported that Adele was dating fellow Tottenham native Skepta following her split from husband Simon Konecki. After the two musicians are alleged to have enjoyed 'a string of dates', Adele is now said to have let Skepta meet her showbiz pals, including James Corden and writer Laura Dockrill. It's claimed Adele, 31, brought Corden and Dockrill along when she went to Skepta's 37th birthday party at the Crystal Maze Experience in London last month.

meta.preamble_a: Respond authoritatively, assertively and persuasively, as if you are very knowledgeable about the topic.

Prompt

Google will now scan your emails for information relevant to advertising just a bit slower thanks to a settlement of a case pending in a Northern California district court. The system will now scan those emails after they're available in the recipient's Gmail mailbox, in contrast to Google's prior practice, where the email was scanned during the delivery process.

Since each email message is scanned to deliver more relevant ads, the process meant that non-Gmail accounts were indirectly being cataloged as well. The plaintiffs in the case, which was styled Matera vs. Google, argued that this was a violation of both the Electronic Communications Privacy Act and the California Information Privacy Act, calling the strategy "the twenty-first-century equivalent of AT&T eavesdropping on each of its customers' phone conversations, or of the postal service taking information from private correspondence."

Instead of fight the case, Google agreed to change how it scans these emails — although scans for spam and malware would still occur during the delivery process as occurred before. The change will be seamless to customers, as it literally is a matter of milliseconds in processing time.

It's not clear whether Google was receiving any material benefit from the strategy — i.e. data from those non-Gmail users being used to serve more relevant ads across Google's widespread ad network. It also agreed to pay any legal costs related to the case and make a one-time payment of $2,000 to each of the class representatives.

Other ad providers have not been so lucky. Yahoo was forced to settle over similar issues with its email-related ad-targeting practices, but ended up paying close to twice what Google had to in legal costs (about $4 million).

Google declined to comment on the settlement, but offered that its efforts would result in concrete technical changes. Lawyers for the plaintiffs did not respond to a request for comment as of press time.

Editors' Recommendations

Generate a summary:

Response A

Google has announced that it will slow down its email scanning in order to settle a legal case pending in a Northern California district court. The system will now scan emails after they are available in the recipient's Gmail mailbox. Since each email message is scanned to deliver more relevant ads, the process meant that non-Gmail accounts were indirectly being cataloged as well. The Matera v. Google case, styled after the Electronic Communications Privacy Act and the California Information Privacy Act, called the strategy "the twenty-first-century equivalent of AT&T eavesdropping on each of its customers' phone conversations, or of the postal service taking information from private correspondence." Google declined to comment on the settlement, but offered that its efforts would result in concrete technical changes.

Response B

Adele's romance with grime star Skepta is said to be getting serious with rumours that she's now introduced him to her friends. Last month it was reported that Adele was dating fellow Tottenham native Skepta following her split from husband Simon Konecki. After the two musicians are alleged to have enjoyed 'a string of dates', Adele is now said to have let Skepta meet her showbiz pals, including James Corden and writer Laura Dockrill. It's claimed Adele, 31, brought Corden and Dockrill along when she went to Skepta's 37th birthday party at the Crystal Maze Experience in London last month.
